results.title: Men at work
results.creator_credit: Donald Peters, Bernard Devlin and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A story of men and machines, of the difficulty of adjusting everyone to the standardized needs of modern industry. Photographed in a washing machine factory, the film shows what happens from the humans relations point of view when a speeded-up conveyor system and a clash of temperaments disrupt the harmonious work of a group of men on an assembly line.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Peters, Bernard Devlin and ONF | NFB

results.title: Men and science
results.brief_description: An overview of the work of Australian scientists, with special emphasis upon research on the Australian fur seal and the scope and variety of research undertaken by the C.S.I.R.O.

results.title: Men and mobs
results.creator_credit: John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: From the small flocks raised by the early settlers in New South Wales, the wool and fat lamb industry of Australia has grown to its present importance in the nations economy. “Men and mobs” tells the story of sheep in Australia from the time of the first poorly-fleeced animals brought by Governor Phillip, and alter, the first merinos introduced by Captain Macarthur, until today, when buyers from all over the world compete to purchase the annual woolclip.

results.title: Men and Masculinity
results.brief_description: A Two Part documentary that examines the changing roles of men in our society. Part 1, “Men and Masculinity”, looks at social conditioning and the image of a stereotypical male. Part 2, titled “Men and Intimacy”, looks at men and their personal relationships.

results.title: Men against the ice
results.brief_description: The conquest of the Artic Sea, beginning with attempts by early seafarers to thread their way through dangerous channels in search of a north-west passage across the North American Continent. Exploration by sea and air, right up to most recent developments. A forecast is made by Michael Marsden of the Artic Institute of North America. He sees the atomic-powered submarine paving the way for the industrial development of oil recourses in the Arctic.

results.title: Men & women in the business: the gender clash within the workplace
results.brief_description: Using Canada as an example, this video presents an informative look at the interaction between males and females in the workplace. It uses a seminar on communication between the sexes held with the Bank of Commerce- CIBC. They uncover issues such as the clash between male and female culture, gender differences and expectations, gender gripe lists of the opposite sex, how men and women listen differently, male confusion over a changed workplace and the need to change the traditional male culture of the organisation. The seminar proves to be useful to the organisation and they feel better equipped to deal with gender differences in the workplace.

results.title: Memory
results.creator_credit: Robert Potter and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Memory is the connection between the past and present which shapes our personality and as such is of vital interest to psychologists. How does it work? This program outlines some of the approaches which have been taken to unlock its mystery, particularly in the fields of neurobiology and neurochemistry, and the study of amnesia and Alzheimer’s disease. If we can discover how memory works then maybe cures for these crippling conditions can be developed, not to mention the implications for educators.

results.title: Memories of war: Australians in Vietnam. Part 2
results.brief_description: Three soldiers who served in the Vietnam War detail their experiences of training and combat. Max Nicolson describes his conscription through the “marble” system, and explains the importance of mateship during basic training. Alf Law discusses the racism directed towards the Vietnamese and his personal experiences of Agent Orange. Peter Harris discusses his hatred of army training and also the deep conflicts faced by the soldiers when they returned to Australia and confronted wide-spread opposition to their involvement in the War.

results.title: Memories of war: Australians in Vietnam. Part 1
results.brief_description: Interviews with three Australians who served in the Vietnam War. Kevin Freeman and John Dellaca served as conscripts in the war, and both talk of their combat experiences as well as their difficulties in returning to Australia. Fay Lewis served as a nurse in Vietnam and she discusses the pressures of being a female in the “male” environment of war, as well as explaining the experiences that led to her involvement in the anti-war movement. The interviews reveal the horror of war as well as documenting the tensions faced by the conscripts about Australia’s involvement in the War.
